content: The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" is a new law that excludes space-related income from gross income according to section 139B of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" excludes space-related income from gross income under section 139B of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Space-related income includes income from products or services produced in outer space, services performed in outer space, and certain interest, rent, or royalties related to space activities. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" excludes space-related income from gross income under section 139B of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Exceptions include telecommunications services from earth orbit, services from weather or earth observation satellites, and transporting property to or from outer space. Wages and proportional allocation between space-based and earth-based activities are also exempt. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" exempts products manufactured in outer space from federal excises, imposts, duties, and tariffs if launched from or manufactured at a facility owned by US persons. The exclusion amount under this act will be gradually reduced after 2014. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" exempts products made in outer space from federal taxes. The amendments made by this section apply to costs incurred after December 31, 2005. Part I of subchapter P of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include an exclusion for gains from the sale or exchange of stock of qualified space corporations. Gross income excludes gain on the sale or exchange of stock of a qualified space corporation, defined as a domestic C corporation providing products or services in outer space. Expenses must be mostly related to this business activity. The exclusion for gains from the sale or exchange of stock of qualified space corporations applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2005.
